attributes.title: Mobilizing voters to mobilize MPs for a second referendum

q1.value: Mobilizing voters to mobilize MPs for a second referendum

q2.value: Joshua Townsley | Stuart Turnbull-Dugarte | Florian Foos

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: We evaluate the effect of emails on whether supporters of an Anti-Brexit campaign group contact their MP to encourage them to support a second referendum [People’s Vote] on the UK’s exit from the UK [Brexit] via a randomized field experiment conducted by an anti-Brexit campaign group. Supporters of the campaign group that live in constituencies represented by an MP who has not already expressed support for a second referendum on Brexit are randomly assigned to one of three experimental conditions: Receive one of two emails encouraging them to contact their local MP which includes a direct URL that leads them to a pre-designed email for them to sign and forward to their representative, or to control (no email).

q16.value: H1: Email contact from the campaign organisation encouraging their pre-identified supporters to contact their MP lobbying for a second referendum on Brexit will mobilise subjects to contact their MP. H2: The effect of the campaign group’s email on emails sent to MPs will be greater amongst those subjects who are also informed of their MP’s lack of support for a 2nd referendum.

q17.value: The outcome measure is binary and defined as the successful submission of lobbying emails from supporters to their respective MP via the organisation’s online mask. It takes on the value 1 if the email was submitted via the online platform, and the value 0 if no email was submitted. The outcome is measured via a traceable URL that tracks the successful submission of pre- designed emails of supporters using the organisation’s platform. The outcome variable will be collected for 7 days from the delivery of the treatment.

registration_responses.q2: Joshua Townsley | Stuart Turnbull-Dugarte | Florian Foos
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

Supporters of the campaign group that live in constituencies represented by an MP who has not already expressed support for a second referendum on Brexit are randomly assigned to one of three experimental conditions: Receive one of two emails encouraging them to contact their local MP which includes a direct URL that leads them to a pre-designed email for them to sign and forward to their representative, or to control (no email).

The outcome is measured via a traceable URL that tracks the successful submission of pre- designed emails of supporters using the organisation’s platform. The outcome variable will be collected for 7 days from the delivery of the treatment.

attributes.title: Dirty Words in Clean Energy Politics

q1.value: Dirty Words in Clean Energy Politics

q5.value: We would like to thank the Climate Advocacy Lab for providing funding for this research.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study is designed to explore how two aspects of a policy message – the message frame and the message source– influence public support for a clean energy policy like that being discussed under the auspices of the Green New Deal. Clean energy policies have often been framed as either environmental or job-creation policies. The messengers about these policies also range, with environmental organizations, business organizations, and labor organizations being involved in messaging on these policies. It is unclear how the different frames and messages surrounding these policies influence public support for the policies. Using an online survey experiment, we seek to answer the following research questions: • Does public support for a Green New Deal-type policy change based on whether it is framed as a climate change policy or as a clean job creation policy? • How does the source of the message (environmental group vs. business group vs. labor group) affect public support for the policy? • Does framing a policy around climate change and/or jobs reduce attitudinal ambivalence for respondents? If so, how does that affect their support for the policy? • And, finally, how do liberal, moderate, and conservative individuals respond differently to the various framing combinations?

q16.value: Hypotheses differ based on partisanship, as the sources and messages are designed to appeal differently to Democrats and Republicans. We plan to test the following hypotheses, based on the message source and frame combinations. 1. Receiving a climate frame from an environmental organization will increase support for the policy among Democrats but have no effect among Republicans 2. Receiving a jobs frame from an environmental organization will increase support among both Democrats and Republicans 3. Receiving a climate frame from a business organization will increase Republican support but have no effect on support among Democrats 4. Receiving a jobs frame from a business organization will increase Republican support but have no effect on support among Democrats 5. Receiving a climate frame from a labor organization will increase support among Democrats and decrease support among Republicans. 6. Receiving a jobs frame from a labor organization will increase support among Democrats and decrease support among Republicans.

q17.value: We will be using a vignette online survey experiment to test how various ways of framing a clean energy policy will change participant support for the policy. Participants will answer a few upfront questions about their policy attitudes, then will read through three different bill descriptions and note how much they support each bill. In each brief bill description, the message frame and the source will be randomized so that each description presents a different message/source combination. Each participant will read through 3 different bill descriptions, and respond with their level of support for each bill. After the experimental part of the survey, participants will then answer a few remaining demographic questions. The survey questionnaire is attached.

If so, how does that affect their support for the policy? • And, finally, how do liberal, moderate, and conservative individuals respond differently to the various framing combinations?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We study the role of international status concerns among the public in shaping support for political leaders. Political elites behave as though international status—the relative ranking, standing, or position of a country in the global hierarchy—is key to how citizens and observers will evaluate their performance (Paul, Larson, and Wohlforth 2014; Renshon 2017). Indeed, perceived losses of international status and promises to restore it are frequently central themes in national election campaigns. Candidates and other observers, for example, commonly link variation in international status to evaluations of the relative competence or eﬀectiveness of incumbent political leaders. Most of the time, this comes in the form of decrying the stature lost by current or past leaders. Thus, in keeping with a broad and burgeoning literature on prestige, we study the status concerns of voters. Status—either in terms of ranking in a hierarchy or identity as member of a club—is the focus of a vibrant research program on the international level (for a review, see Dafoe, Renshon, and Huth 2014). Status concerns have been linked to MID and war initiation (Volgy and Mayhall 1995), great power rivalry (Wohlforth 2009), defense spending (Gilady 2002), the acquisition of colonies (Barnhart 2013) and broad patters of state behavior (Larson and Shevchenko 2010). In all of this work, we typically learn how the status of states or leaders aﬀects a country’s foreign policy behavior. We reverse this this notion by asking: how does the international status of a country aﬀect its domestic politics?

q16.value: We expect that adverse outcomes in international politics that are beyond the control of political leaders will result in decreased support for those same political leaders (H1). In particular, we expect this to occur because the public becomes concerned about the country losing status or prestige internationally (H2a). For design-based reasons outlined below, we do not expect other potential mechanisms to bind. As such, we expect that concerns about the political leaders competence (H3), concerns about the country's material power and capabilities (H4), or concerns about the states ability to deter future challengers (H5) to be affected by the treatment.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses using an "embedded natural experiment" (Dafoe, Zhang, and Caughey 2015). The experiment will be embedded in a survey of the U.S. public. We will introduce a hypothetical scenario in which the U.S. president is seeking to prevent the U.K. from joining a new Chinese-led international organization. The president's policy choices and behavior are fixed across treatment conditions. In the first treatment condition, the UK does not join the IO because of an unexpected fiscal crisis at home. In the second treatment condition, the UK does join the IO. We expect approval of the president to be higher in the first treatment condition because UK membership in the new IO would suggest that the U.S. is less influential than it once was. We expect that this challenge to U.S. leadership will increase concerns about status among respondents. The experiment is designed to allow status concerns to vary as a result of treatment while fixing outcomes for three other causal pathways. First, we fix perceptions of the competency of the political leader by holding the behavior and policy choices of the political leader constant across treatment conditions. Second, we fix deterrence concerns both by fixing the behavior and policy choices of political leaders across treatment conditions and by selecting an issue area—the politics of IO governance—in which the public is unlikely to link outcomes to the ability of the U.S. to deter military aggression. Finally, relative power concerns are fixed in a similar manner, though it is plausible that some respondents may draw conclusions about the military power and capabilities of the U.S. from the effect that the outcome in each treatment condition has on the economic influence of the U.S. Still, given that the issue area is fairly removed from military contests and nothing in the scenario queues on military we expect this effect to be minimal.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

attributes.title: The Origins of Tax Compliance and State Capacity

q1.value: The Origins of Tax Compliance and State Capacity

q2.value: Pablo Balan | Augustin Bergeron | Gabriel Tourek | Jonathan Weigel

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: What are the barriers to raising revenues in developing countries? With the goal of reducing reliance on foreign aid and natural resources, many governments seek to build tax bases among citizens who operate predominantly within the informal sector. Recent research has documented the difficulty of encouraging citizens in these contexts to enter the formal sector and regularly pay taxes. This study explores three understudied determinants of low tax compliance. First, low-capacity states are typically weak at protecting property rights. Second, inefficient methods of tax collection may constrain the effectiveness of enforcement. Third, when citizens face high liquidity constrains, compliance may be elastic to the tax burden. We will assess the effect of these factors on tax compliance with a randomized field experiment that implements interventions affecting each of these margins through a collaboration with the Provincial Government of Kasaï Central in Kananga, Democratic Republic of the Congo, from August 2017 to December 2018. We will vary (1) subsidized access to formal land titles, (2) the method of tax collection—comparing centralized and local collection—and (3) the property tax rates faced by house- holds. Our Pre-Analysis Plan presents the research design and introduces the hypotheses pertaining to the land titling intervention. It will be updated after a pilot of the tax intervention in early 2018 to include hypotheses pertaining to taxation before endline data collection.

q16.value: Please refer to our PAP for detailed discussion of the hypotheses to be tested and the quantities of interest to be estimated.

q17.value: Please refer to our PAP for detailed discussion of our experimental design.

attributes.title: Permission to Secede? The Impact of Foreign Powers on Separatist Movements

q1.value: Permission to Secede? The Impact of Foreign Powers on Separatist Movements

q5.value: The authors are grateful to the Europe Center for their generosity in funding this project..

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Over the last decade, several referendums on secession have taken place across the globe. Europe alone recently witnessed referendums in Crimea (March 2014), Luhansk and Donetsk (March 2014), Scotland (September 2014), and Catalonia (October 2017). Existin g political science scholarship on secession emphasizes two characteristics that make it difficult to explain recent European separatist movements. First, traditional secessionist literature tends to focus on cases in non - democratic or weakly democratic st ates, often characterized by instability and political violence. Second, secessionist literature focuses predominately on sub - natio nal bargaining between relevant domestic actors --- traditionally the central government and an opposing rebel group. Recently, sc holarship has tended to highlight the international dimensions of separatist movements, analyzing the role of foreign support and providing evide nce that these movements may diffuse across time and space . In this stu dy, we co nduct a survey experiment in Scotland to examine the mi cro - lev e l effects of international views on secession on public attitudes . S pecifically , we test whether expressions of sup port or opposition made by regional powers directly impact popular views toward secessionist movements . We also examine the mechanisms through which international support or opposition influence public opinion.

q16.value: H0 : Statements made by the European Union in support of or opposition to secessionist movements do no impact popular support of these movements. H1 : EU Support o f secession increases popular support toward secession compared to EU opposition of secession. H2A : The EU's effect on attitudes toward secession will be through emphasizing statehood's material benefits, such as economic opportunity and political stability . H2B : The EU's effect on attitudes toward secession will be through emphasizing statehood's immaterial benefits, such as international legitimacy and national identity

q17.value: Using a survey experiment where we w ill randomly present respondents with a statement of support or opposition of secession by the EU . We will also ask respondents several questions to ex amine the mechanism.

registration_responses.q1: Permission to Secede? The Impact of Foreign Powers on Separatist Movements
registration_responses.q5: The authors are grateful to the Europe Center for their generosity in funding this project..

Second, secessionist literature focuses predominately on sub - natio nal bargaining between relevant domestic actors --- traditionally the central government and an opposing rebel group. Recently, sc holarship has tended to highlight the international dimensions of separatist movements, analyzing the role of foreign support and providing evide nce that these movements may diffuse across time and space . In this stu dy, we co nduct a survey experiment in Scotland to examine the mi cro - lev e l effects of international views on secession on public attitudes . H1 : EU Support o f secession increases popular support toward secession compared to EU opposition of secession. H2A : The EU's effect on attitudes toward secession will be through emphasizing statehood's material benefits, such as economic opportunity and political stability . H2B : The EU's effect on attitudes toward secession will be through emphasizing statehood's immaterial benefits, such as international legitimacy and national identity
registration_responses.q17: Using a survey experiment where we w ill randomly present respondents with a statement of support or opposition of secession by the EU . We will also ask respondents several questions to ex amine the mechanism.

attributes.title: What Motivates Citizens to Trust Political Leaders? Probing the Evaluative Criteria Underlying Trust in Political Actors

q1.value: What Motivates Citizens to Trust Political Leaders? Probing the Evaluative Criteria Underlying Trust in Political Actors

q2.value: Ebe Ouattara | Eefje Steenvoorden | Tom van der Meer

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Political trust is often conceptualized as an evaluative and relational attitude in which a subject A, trusts an object B to perform a particular action X (Hardin, 2000). Focusing on each component of this framework, scholars have pointed to particular traits and values of the subject (A), characteristics of the object (B) and domains and scope of action (X) to explain rising or declining levels of political trust. Despite this wealth of knowledge, the evaluative framework of political trust remains limited by a dearth of empirical research about the criteria that matter most in citizens’ evaluations of political leaders. While attitudes of trust are often conceptualized as multidimensional and relying on a range of evaluative criteria such as ability, integrity and benevolence (Mayer et al. 1995), little research has been conducted to show how and whether these criteria actually matter in the formation of citizens’ trust attitudes toward political leaders. Our aim in this project is to provide a better understanding of the evaluative processes underlying citizens’ political trust attitudes. First (1) we seek to better understand which standards citizens use to evaluate the trustworthiness of political actors and how much weight they place on these standards. Secondly, we will assess how citizens’ characteristics, values and preferences condition the salience of various criteria in their trust judgments. Doing so will enable us to gain better insights about the relational nature of political trust between citizens and their representatives. It will also enable us to narrow the gap between theoretical conceptualizations of political trust which mostly frame this attitude as a multi-dimensional evaluation based on various criteria, and empirical studies in which hypothesized evaluative processes underlying trust judgments often remain confined to a black box of agnosticism or a few factors falling under the umbrella of competence or performance.

q16.value: Drawing on existing studies, we identify 9 evaluative criteria commonly said to influence judgments of political trust: (1) Competence, (2) Vigor/ Decisiveness, (3) Benevolence, (4) Care, (5) Predictability, (6) Openness and Transparency, (7) Integrity, (8) Charisma, (9) Empathy. Our first goal is to investigate which of these characteristics people hold in mind when they assess the trustworthiness of political actors. While we do not expect all criteria to have the same effect on judgments of trust, we cannot claim to know a-priori which of these criteria will matter most. This part of the analysis will mostly be exploratory. Nevertheless, we can begin to answer this first set of questions by proposing a number of general hypotheses about the role of these traits in evaluations of political trust. In line with an evaluative conceptualization of trust, we expect that citizens’ trust in a political actor will be influenced by their evaluations of these criteria. Hence, we expect that: H1: The more positive traits/characteristics a politician possesses, the more trust citizens will be willing to place in her/him. We expect these effects to be cumulative in nature such that: H2 (Interaction): The higher the number of positive characteristics used to describe a politician, the more citizens will trust her/him. But due to negativity bias, we expect that: H3 (Interaction): The combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a negative evaluation of the trustworthiness of a political actor. Hypotheses about the Relational Nature of Political Trust Evaluations H4 (Interaction): Citizens who cite a particular norm/characteristic as an important component of their evaluations of trust will place more weight on this characteristic in their evaluations of trust in a political actor. H5 (Interaction): Partisan affiliation moderates evaluations of political trust such that non-partisans evaluate the trustworthiness of political actors from an opposing party more negatively than co-partisans. Beyond the asymmetric nature of the broader trust judgment, we also expect partisan evaluative biases to influence the weight citizen place on positive and negative descriptions of trustworthiness traits. Building on our third hypothesis (H3) about the combination of positive and negative characteristics, we expect: H6 (Interaction): For non-partisans, the combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a negative evaluation of the trustworthiness of that political actor. (Conversely, for co-partisans, the combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a positive evaluation of the trustworthiness of that political actor.)

q17.value: To test these hypotheses we propose two between-person factorial survey experiments. The vignettes used in these experiments consist of a hypothetical scenario in which a local politician is appointed to replace a resigning MP. Respondents are presented with a description of the local politician in which the characteristics/attributes of the politician are randomized along: 1. Party affiliation (1 of 3 Dutch political parties), 2. Gender (Male or Female), and 3. Nine trustworthiness criteria with 2 levels (positive or negative) listed in the Hypotheses and Quantities of Interest Section. In experiment 1, we will employ a full factorial design, randomizing party affiliation, gender and all 9 trust characteristics of the politician along 2 levels (positive or negative). This results in a 3x2^10 full factorial design with 3072 unique vignette profiles. Experiment 2 is nearly identical with the exception that the vignette consists of a random selection of 1 of the 9 trust characteristics along 2 levels (positive or negative). This results in a 3x2x18 full factorial design with 108 unique vignette profiles. We primarily employ this split design as a robustness check to ensure that our findings are consistent in instances when respondents make a rather unidimensional evaluation based on a single trustworthiness characteristics as well as situations in which evaluations occur along multidimensional lines with nine different trust characteristics. The between-person design entails that each respondent will be assigned to a unique randomized vignette. Analytically, we will test our hypotheses of interest by assessing differences between individuals’ trust ratings that are attributable to specific components of the vignettes. The effects of these components represent a marginal effect averaged across all vignette conditions. We aim to present our findings by (1) providing descriptive differences in means of the components of interest across all vignettes. (2) Given the rating/ordinal nature of our dependent variable, we will test our hypotheses of interest by employing ordered logistic regressions. Moreover, we will rely on the AMCE, conditional AMCEs and ACIE estimates as defined by Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto (2014) in testing these hypotheses.

q19.value: ~ 25,000 - We expect to work with a sample size of approximately 25,000 individuals. It is not possible for the researchers to manipulate this sample size. Half of the sample will be randomly assigned to experiment 1 and the other half to experiment 2.

q21.value: We conducted a simulation-based power analysis for a factorial experiment with 2^10 conditions. – Simulation based diagnosis of the design could not be conducted on a standard machine for a 3*2^10 factorial experiment.

q27.value: EenVandaag → The EenVanDaag research team will conduct data collection.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

While attitudes of trust are often conceptualized as multidimensional and relying on a range of evaluative criteria such as ability, integrity and benevolence (Mayer et al. 1995), little research has been conducted to show how and whether these criteria actually matter in the formation of citizens’ trust attitudes toward political leaders. Our aim in this project is to provide a better understanding of the evaluative processes underlying citizens’ political trust attitudes. First (1) we seek to better understand which standards citizens use to evaluate the trustworthiness of political actors and how much weight they place on these standards. Secondly, we will assess how citizens’ characteristics, values and preferences condition the salience of various criteria in their trust judgments. Doing so will enable us to gain better insights about the relational nature of political trust between citizens and their representatives. It will also enable us to narrow the gap between theoretical conceptualizations of political trust which mostly frame this attitude as a multi-dimensional evaluation based on various criteria, and empirical studies in which hypothesized evaluative processes underlying trust judgments often remain confined to a black box of agnosticism or a few factors falling under the umbrella of competence or performance.
registration_responses.q16: Drawing on existing studies, we identify 9 evaluative criteria commonly said to influence judgments of political trust: (1) Competence, (2) Vigor/ Decisiveness, (3) Benevolence, (4) Care, (5) Predictability, (6) Openness and Transparency, (7) Integrity, (8) Charisma, (9) Empathy. Our first goal is to investigate which of these characteristics people hold in mind when they assess the trustworthiness of political actors. While we do not expect all criteria to have the same effect on judgments of trust, we cannot claim to know a-priori which of these criteria will matter most. This part of the analysis will mostly be exploratory. Nevertheless, we can begin to answer this first set of questions by proposing a number of general hypotheses about the role of these traits in evaluations of political trust. In line with an evaluative conceptualization of trust, we expect that citizens’ trust in a political actor will be influenced by their evaluations of these criteria. Hence, we expect that: H1: The more positive traits/characteristics a politician possesses, the more trust citizens will be willing to place in her/him. We expect these effects to be cumulative in nature such that: H2 (Interaction): The higher the number of positive characteristics used to describe a politician, the more citizens will trust her/him. But due to negativity bias, we expect that: H3 (Interaction): The combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a negative evaluation of the trustworthiness of a political actor. Hypotheses about the Relational Nature of Political Trust Evaluations H4 (Interaction): Citizens who cite a particular norm/characteristic as an important component of their evaluations of trust will place more weight on this characteristic in their evaluations of trust in a political actor. H5 (Interaction): Partisan affiliation moderates evaluations of political trust such that non-partisans evaluate the trustworthiness of political actors from an opposing party more negatively than co-partisans. Beyond the asymmetric nature of the broader trust judgment, we also expect partisan evaluative biases to influence the weight citizen place on positive and negative descriptions of trustworthiness traits. Building on our third hypothesis (H3) about the combination of positive and negative characteristics, we expect: H6 (Interaction): For non-partisans, the combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a negative evaluation of the trustworthiness of that political actor. (Conversely, for co-partisans, the combination of positive and negative traits about a particular politician will overall lead to a positive evaluation of the trustworthiness of that political actor.)
registration_responses.q17: To test these hypotheses we propose two between-person factorial survey experiments. The vignettes used in these experiments consist of a hypothetical scenario in which a local politician is appointed to replace a resigning MP. Respondents are presented with a description of the local politician in which the characteristics/attributes of the politician are randomized along: 1. Party affiliation (1 of 3 Dutch political parties), 2. Gender (Male or Female), and 3. Nine trustworthiness criteria with 2 levels (positive or negative) listed in the Hypotheses and Quantities of Interest Section. In experiment 1, we will employ a full factorial design, randomizing party affiliation, gender and all 9 trust characteristics of the politician along 2 levels (positive or negative). This results in a 3x2^10 full factorial design with 3072 unique vignette profiles. Experiment 2 is nearly identical with the exception that the vignette consists of a random selection of 1 of the 9 trust characteristics along 2 levels (positive or negative). This results in a 3x2x18 full factorial design with 108 unique vignette profiles. We primarily employ this split design as a robustness check to ensure that our findings are consistent in instances when respondents make a rather unidimensional evaluation based on a single trustworthiness characteristics as well as situations in which evaluations occur along multidimensional lines with nine different trust characteristics. The between-person design entails that each respondent will be assigned to a unique randomized vignette. Analytically, we will test our hypotheses of interest by assessing differences between individuals’ trust ratings that are attributable to specific components of the vignettes. The effects of these components represent a marginal effect averaged across all vignette conditions. We aim to present our findings by (1) providing descriptive differences in means of the components of interest across all vignettes. (2) Given the rating/ordinal nature of our dependent variable, we will test our hypotheses of interest by employing ordered logistic regressions. Moreover, we will rely on the AMCE, conditional AMCEs and ACIE estimates as defined by Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto (2014) in testing these hypotheses.
registration_responses.q19: ~ 25,000 - We expect to work with a sample size of approximately 25,000 individuals. It is not possible for the researchers to manipulate this sample size. Half of the sample will be randomly assigned to experiment 1 and the other half to experiment 2.
registration_responses.q21: We conducted a simulation-based power analysis for a factorial experiment with 2^10 conditions. – Simulation based diagnosis of the design could not be conducted on a standard machine for a 3*2^10 factorial experiment.
registration_responses.q27: EenVandaag → The EenVanDaag research team will conduct data collection.

attributes.title: How Parties Reduce Citizens’ Political Trust

q1.value: How Parties Reduce Citizens’ Political Trust

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Studies show that citizens who have lost trust in the political institution are prone to cast an anti-establishment vote for populist parties. Yet, we know very little about how or whether parties can erode levels of political trust among citizens. This experiment sets out to examine how party cues are able to shape citizens’ political trust, and whether radical right parties’ rhetoric may dampen not only voters’ political trust but also democratic legitimacy.

q16.value: H1: Party cues containing distrust in political institutions decrease trust among partisans, especially among AfD supporters H2: (Dis)trust cues should also affect levels of democratic legitimacy among partisans H3: (Dis)trust cues should increase acceptance of illegal behavior. H4: Respondents’ subjective social status moderates the effects of H1-H3.

q17.value: We develop and conduct a survey experiment with a nationally representative sample of citizens in Germany. Survey participants are recruited by the online survey company. The survey is conducted in German. Below we provide the experiment treatment and the survey questions.

registration_responses.q1: How Parties Reduce Citizens’ Political Trust
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

Yet, we know very little about how or whether parties can erode levels of political trust among citizens. This experiment sets out to examine how party cues are able to shape citizens’ political trust, and whether radical right parties’ rhetoric may dampen not only voters’ political trust but also democratic legitimacy.

H4: Respondents’ subjective social status moderates the effects of H1-H3.

attributes.title: Randomised Evaluation of La Poste Component of Innajim Campaign

q1.value: Randomised Evaluation of La Poste Component of Innajim Campaign

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The Innajim campaign aims to improve knowledge about, positive perceptions of, and participation in entrepreneurial activities in Tunisia. The campaign is especially targeted at young entrepreneurs and women. There are various longer-term objectives of the project, including the creation of new businesses, female empowerment, and improvement in the economic conditions of young Tunisians, and improving perceptions of the Tunisian government. To obtain this, the project entails a variety of marketing and outreach efforts targetting different audiences through print, broadcast, and online media in tandem with more intensive localised engagement activities. The purpose of this document is to outline a planned randomised evaluation of one portion of the Innamjim project: namely, a partnership with La Poste Tunisienne to provide intensive but heavily localised exposure to campaign messages via a month-long marketing and engagement campaign.

q19.value: 50 respondents per site for 60 sites (total n=3000)

q23.value: This study is not subject to full board ethics review at the London School of Economics and Political Science and has instead been reviewed by the School’s standard ethical self-certification process.

q27.value: The intervention will be implemented by La Poste Tunisienne in collaboration with the UK Cabinet Office and in-country marketing teams. Data collection will be handled by an in-country vendor, One to One.

registration_responses.q1: Randomised Evaluation of La Poste Component of Innajim Campaign
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

The campaign is especially targeted at young entrepreneurs and women. There are various longer-term objectives of the project, including the creation of new businesses, female empowerment, and improvement in the economic conditions of young Tunisians, and improving perceptions of the Tunisian government. To obtain this, the project entails a variety of marketing and outreach efforts targetting different audiences through print, broadcast, and online media in tandem with more intensive localised engagement activities. The purpose of this document is to outline a planned randomised evaluation of one portion of the Innamjim project: namely, a partnership with La Poste Tunisienne to provide intensive but heavily localised exposure to campaign messages via a month-long marketing and engagement campaign.
